posts.content:
Hello elite NWN character builders, 
I'm a big fan of the Baldur's Gate series. Now that the Enhanced Edition of NWN came out, I thought I'd give it a try. In BG I really enjoyed playing as a blade. I like being able to buff up to near invincibility and then deal out heaps and heaps of damage very quickly. I also like to double wield, just because it's cool. Now I've read a little about character creation in NWN and I feel attracted to a Bard 16/Fighter 14/RDD 10 Build. I plan to use it just for the official campaign (OC, SoU, HotU), so I think I will only be able to get it to about level 30 max in this setting. Racewise I prefer human or half-elf. Alignment-wise I usually enjoy playing good guys (not lawful but rather chaotic).

Now my questions: 
  • For the starting stats I see a lot of builds sacrificing dexterity or constitution to get lots of STR. Is it worth it? Wouldn't I get more stat points overall if I start fairly leveled (Like everything 14, except Wisdom 8)
  • Are there any items that make up weak stats in the OC/Expansions? Like the Dexterity-Gloves in BG?
  • Is dual wielding worth the costs? How do I get the most damage per round: double Scimitars or should I rather go for a 2-handed weapon like a greatsword or a scythe? 
  • I like being able to cast some spells as it makes the character more versatile and fun. I don't mind taking off armor before big fights. How much spellcasting makes sense in a build like this? What are especially good spells? In BG I mostly used spells for buffing, but some AoE debuffing or damage spells are also nice. You could even get to cast Time Stops regularly with a simulacrum using a scroll. Are there similar tricks in NWN?
  • I'm not a big fan of ranged attacks. I find it more fun to be able to get close to the enemy and hurt with lots of damage quickly. Are there good items that enhance speed in the OC and expansions? Like the boots of speed in BG.
I'm sure I'm there have to be some builds here that would fit my profile. I have been trying to find them but get overwhelmed by the possibilities. As a newbie I find it hard to weigh pros and cons of the different builds. 

I liked some aspects of these builds: 
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/NWN-P ... 125666238/ 
http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/buil ... 95827.html
Draconic Swordsman v.1/v.2

All of them have low Dex and would not work with dual wielding. Others sacrifice CHA for STR and end up with little or no spells, so none of them are a perfect fit. Any ideas?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: I want to caution you against playing the OC, SoU, and HotU with a single character.  Both the OC and SoU are meant to start at level 1, and HotU is intended to follow SoU.  Instead, play the OC followed by the Mines of Twin Summit series to get all the way to level 40, and then play Sou, HotU, and the Sands of Fate series to get all the way to level 40 again.  This RDD build would be great for SoF, and while it would also work in MotS, use a different build for MotS (an unarmed Monk build or a Weapon Master build are good choices).  Using the same build all the time would get monotonous.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
On the Tendorizing Tenor build, I have great respect for the principles...however, there are issues. No Blind Fighting, Knockdown/IKD not taken until epic levels (same for Curse Song in the initial build). There is a way to get them in pre-epic, and that is to only use one weapon type. Not only does that give you all 3 feats pre-epic (as well as Curse Song if you follow the second levelling guide) - replacing a Weapon Focus, Weapon Specialization, and Improved Critical in the other weapon - it also frees up EWF, EWS, OC, and DC in the second weapon in epic levels, meaning you can take a further 4 Great Strengths, thereby improving both your AB and damage by 2.

It does, of course, have a downside - and that is losing one damage type, either slashing or bludgeoning, so any enemy with a resistance to one type or the other will be harder to handle (for example, Undead and Constructs are more vulnerable to bludgeoning damage and have a resistance to slashing/piercing).

On balance, I think the benefits of taking only one weapon type outweigh its downside. However, I wouldn't go for scimitar, because it's a medium-sized weapon, and dual-wielding them gives you a -4 AB on each hand, rather than the -2 dual-wielding with a small or tiny weapon gives you. The smart choice would be short-swords, but there is a case for handaxes. Another alternative would be to sacrifice Improved KD, take Exotic Weapon Proficiency, then focus in kukris.

Just my thoughts!

Cheers

If you want to take advantage of the full level 40 build, you might want to look at some modules that enable that. Mines of Twin Summit will take you forward from the end of the OC up to level 40. posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
There is a reason I chose specifically a shortsword, besides the smaller dual-wielding penalty.  In early HotU, you encounter a talking longsword.  In your first conversation, you have an opportunity to tell him you don't need a longsword, and he will offer to change to another weapon: a dagger, shortsword, or greatsword.  Not only is it fun to have a talking sword, but he has Vampiric Regeneration (+4, IIRC), which is really nice to have.

It looks like you are taking several pre-epic feats in epic levels, a sign that you are trying to cram too much into the build.  I recommend that you drop dual wielding, using a (talking) longsword and shield.  Leave your DEX at 12, and spend the 2 points to raise your starting STR to 15.  Use all your level +1s on STR.  Also, drop the Exotic Weapons.  All of this should allow you to take 2 or maybe 4 more Great Strength feats, and you can have both Epic Prowess and Armor Skin, rather than having to choose one.

Since you are waiting until epic levels to take Lingering Song, you might as well take Lasting Inspiration instead, for an even longer song, unless you will not be meeting the Bard 20 requirement.

Luck of Heroes is really nice to have if you have feats to spare, but it doesn't belong in such a feat-starved build.
